commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Spirit guide?  (3)(4)
2. Provide a brief glimpse?  (4)(4)
3. Oh, brothers, where art thou?  (6)
4. It requires a flipper  (4)(4)
5. Feature of a safe landing, perhaps  (4)


BAR MENU
DROP TROU
ABBEYS
COIN TOSS
RAIL
In the app on an iPhone, the second EMOTICON didn’t display, leading to a very odd clue.

The rabbit farmer had a bad hare day.

(But his friends don't carrot all.)
Congrats on you debut and persistence! Smooth puzzle

Pardon me for splitting hairs, but in what sense does a bald person have anything that grows on anyone?

A fun puzzle, none the less.  I’m impressed with the perseverance of the constructor in continuing efforts after so many rejections.
Nice flow for a Monday. Had to read the explanation for growing on you. Didn’t make sense until then. However I had no difficulty with the puzzle
Nice relaxing puzzle. I took the time to mullet over.

The 55D that I keep watching fall from the sky is a bit of a BUZZKILL, but nothing about this puzzle is! A SLEW of ZEST and a fun theme! 

Congrats (from a Gopher) on a great debut, Ryan—and nicely done on the perseverance! I hope you will be HAIR to stay in the constructing business!

Isn't it ironic that one thing this puzzle was *not* was "hairy." A breezy delight is what it was for me. To those who would object to BALD as a themer, I would like to remind that baldness is not always permanent and hair does grow back. A while back, I was bald due to chemo and now I have a full head of hair (yay!) Also, some people might just choose to shave their head and then let their hair grow back. So yeah, BALD can definitely work in the context of IT'S GROWING ON ME. Side note: When I was BALD, I learned really quickly why bald people wear HATS. Especially in the Winter, boy does it get freezing up there. Beanies to the rescue! But I also wore a wig which not only kept the head warm, it earned me so many compliments on my beautiful hair and/or beautiful haircut, I would laugh the rest of the day. And, to wrap up the topic, as the grand-daughter of a bald man, the niece of a bald man, and the sister of a bald man, all of which didn't/don't have the option of regrowing hair, I just want to say, "Bald men of this Earth, I salute you" (and let me start with the baldest of heart-throbs...Sir Patrick Stewart.) For today, the song I'm inspired to post is not "LET it be," gorgeous as it is, nor an AFRO-CUBAN one, but rather Radiohead's beautiful "Street Spirit (FADE Out)" – https://youtu.be/LCJblaUkkfc?si=I70lE05zDbPhLT4U Congratulations on your NYT puzzle debut, Ryan, as well as on your persistence and resilience. I'm so grateful for all three!
Congratulations on your debut puzzle, Ryan!  A thoroughly enjoyable Monday. Glad you stuck with it.

I myself sport a tilde hairstyle. This is what I look like 

~:-)

Speaking of brows, I used to have a mono-brow, and this is what I looked like back then:

~I:-(

Recently, I let my tilde go and it became a SNARL:

$%
*&~~~: - )
(((#

Even more recently, the tilde ran away with a question mark, and they met up with an interrobang (don't ask, don't tell). One day I woke, and it was just gone. It wasn't good for my ego, nor was the keto diet I was on: several ozs of Cheez-its per minute and no sit-ups. Plus, my mono-brow grew back:

I:-(

But this morning, a pair of curly brackets settled on my head and I stopped feeling like a gothic hobo and more like I had a new lease on life:

{{:-)

Ryan, from another Wisconsinite, love the puzzle.

Reminder to you and your fellow school mates, please do your civic duty on Tuesday. Vitally important.

I have to admit some serious problems in the extreme southwest.

17D [Happy: Sp] and 63A [Citrus peel] very nearly did me in early in the week,

Could it be I'm not as stunningly brilliant as I think I am?

Naw, must the the constructors fault.  😀
Nearly got the rare sub-9-minute Monday puzzle, but I’ve never seen the Andy Griffith Show and… didn’t know what a HABO or a HEBO was. We all have those days :p
Nice work on the Z’s, Ryan! Especially happy (Sp) crossing the peel!
Love the theme!

Congratulations on a solid NYT debut, Mr. Mathiason! Your perseverance is impressive and inspiring. 

Good luck with your studies, and I hope you’ll be back here soon!

My last squares to fall were, unsurprisingly, in the cluster of CNBC, LEAH, BALL UP and CHEEZE. Had I not recalled the Biblical name - which I must have seen before in these puzzles - which gave me more crosses to trigger recollections (also from NYT grids) of CNBC and CHEEZE, I would probably have needed lookups. 

I know I would have googled around there a year or 18 months ago, when I was greener at this.

BALL UP is nothing unusual, but it just did not come to me on its own.

As for going bald, a trichologist can help you. One did wonders for me, and generally helped me improve my health by linking scalp issues to various things that were wrong with me (bad diet, vitamin D deficiency, etc.). Also, there is medication for male pattern baldness. These days I have more hair than I know what to do with 🤣. It's also much stronger than it was before. Awesome stuff.

Nice Monday puzzle! Happy to see the BALD EAGLE entry since I’ve been a little obsessed with the eagles’ nest live cam at Big Bear Valley: https://www.youtube.com/live/B4-L2nfGcuE?si=z_hxxnrvDCupiot9 We’ve been seeing a few baldies here in Oakland and have hopes that they’re nesting!
Welcome back Monday puzzle! Thank you NYT. Feel remotely competent again

excuse me this was created by the Creator his first puzzle and its better than most Sundays for the last FOREVER

PERIOD

I have always felt that bald is bold—a sign of dome-ination.  (Let us not split hairs.)


🧑‍🦲🧑‍🦲🧑‍🦲🧑‍🦲🧑‍🦲

Today I tried to solve using only the across clues. It was harder than I expected! First I had to work pretty hard not to see the down clues (using an iPad, would have been easier on a phone or paper). Then I just couldn't get them all, my downfall being CNBC. "Well, any combo of letters could go here..." 

Sort of a fun exercise, but then I missed fun clues like Producers of six-packs and Kids in the 90s.

When you’ve been doing this awhile, Mondays can frequently solve on autopilot. Plus, if you’ve passed 40 but are too vain to wear glasses (and absolutely, categorically refuse to do that thing where you own several pairs and place them strategically around the house, because you’re not your mom—yet), you may frequently solve with vision so blurry that the alphabet reduces to maybe 15 unique letters. And then if you’re solving while waiting for the first snoozed alarm to go off again…

All this to say that it took me embarrassingly long to parse (and correct) those kids in the 90s whose moniker of ASTUtE NT’S I just couldn’t remember ever hearing, and to stop pronouncing STARANISE to rhyme with ‘sterilize.’

All’s well that ends well. Except, of course, that it’s still Monday. But there’s a cure for that, one that will travel well in a handy 20-oz thermos and make an astute nt out of just about anyone. 

Have a good day, fellow Wordplayers.
I didn’t have any problem solving 50D: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vcM1kTZm-nM

What a great Monday start. An attractive puzzle that was Monday light. I imagine that’s difficult to pull off, so kudos to Mr Mathiason.

STAR ANISE is one of my favourite spices; I add it to everything, including my tea if I don’t want milk.

I BUZZ my DH’s BALD head once a month to keep the dome shiny smooth.
 Note to other hairless gentlemen; DH has recently been diagnosed with squamous cell skin cancer on said dome. None melanoma, caught very early and (we hope) totally removed. He gets final results next month but the consultant is pretty happy. The cause; his stubbornness in refusing to wear either hat or sun cream for decades. He’s an outdoors man and I’ve been nagging him forever. This has finally persuaded him to do the right thing. Guys; as the Aussies say, ‘slop on the cream, slap on a hat, slip on a tee’ I may be paraphrasing slightly. You know it makes sense.
Your persistence paid off, Ryan.  Congratulations on an excellent debut.

Nice Monday puzzle; glad to see another new constructor. This was just a bit on the slow side for me with a couple of unfamiliar things (STARANISE, e.g.) that had to be worked from the crosses. No big deal - clever theme though I must confess that I'm not grasping exactly how FADE fits into the sequence. 

That's all on me. No big deal. I'll put my usual puzzle finds in a reply (or two). 

...

I thought it more difficult than usual for a Monday, but that just made the fun last a little longer.  Like others, very impressed with Ryan's perseverance.  

I remember The Andy Griffith show and especially liked Opie, who had some very moving scenes.

Very smooth today.
I'm assuming Debbie Downer is an idiom? And buzzkill is like killjoy.

Why are 90's kids A students please?
I discovered that Cheez-Its were introduced to the UK last September! An instinct tells me that they're not classed as a 'healthy snack'.
Fabulous debut, Ryan!

Wow, Ryan, I am glad you persisted in your quest, and that you are now among the amazing contributors whose puzzles entertain me daily here in the NYT. Forty times, now that is dogged! 
Congratulations on your triumph today. I enjoyed your debut crossword puzzle so much. I hope every one of your next forty makes its way to these pages!

10D seems to be cut off after the word “and” for me.  App issue?

Congratulations on the debut, Ryan!

Decades ago, I played saxophone in a soul group, and our manager would shave his head on June 1 every year.  He said it would guarantee a lush head of hair, and it sure did in his case.  

Anyway, this bald-to-afro puzzle whooshed me back into those days – the people in it, the gig, scary and wonderful things that happened – memories that have been dormant for many decades.  For a few moments, I was right back there.  What a gift!  

Regarding the puzzle, I liked a pair of serendipitous echoes:
•	“King of the road” in one clue and “King of the gods” in another.
•	Theme echoes that made me think of hair: SNARL, BALL UP, BROW, HATS, GELS, SET, A PART.

I also liked seeing SNOW falling in the SE, and the trochaic train of long-O enders (LEO, EGO, NATO, AFRO, PESO, HOBO, KETO).

And the inspiring backstory that Ryan kept going through 39 puzzle rejections.  Wow!  

So much lovely out of a simple box.  Congratulations on your debut, Ryan, and thank you for such a rich start to my day!
Congratulations on your debut.  Well done.
Tricky clues?  I would have welcomed a few of those because there was nothing tricky about this puzzle.  Here's hoping the creator uses a sharper pencil next time.

A nice crossword and my fastest fill since I started doing the NYT last month. And no resorting to google or look-ups to confirm my guesses. There were about five new names or phrases to me but the crossers helped out. Or in the case of CHEEZ it became an obvious guess which also helped with CNBC and BUZZKILL
Especially clever!  Well done!  Enjoyed!

Mondays are always over too quickly.
GROWL before SNARL; I guess a snarl is more menacing, as it would involve a show of teeth...

Never heard of:  FADE-AWAY (one word? Two? Hyphenated?)
AFROCUBAN was also new to me.  

Jacob had two wives--and LEAh wasn't the one he wanted; RACHEL must have been pretty long in the tooth by the time he earned her hand in marriage, given life expectancies back then... The father of the girls ran a SCAM on Jake....

This is a comment regarding the mini puzzle for today...

As far as I know SPAM only refers to communication via email, texting, etc on the Internet. I don't think it includes phone calls.

Strands. No spoilers, please, before "view all replies".

Strands #393
“That's an equine of a different shade!”
🔵🔵🔵🟡
🔵🔵

Done with equanimity.

The only thing I found confusing this morning was Sam's EMOTICON:  <3] —  ???

An upside-down heart on a platter?
A double-scoop ice cream cone in a bowl?

I never liked the phrase "Man up", but BALL UP is worse.

A perfect Monday, debut or not!

But 37D is plain wrong. I MAY clearly means I won't.

I loved today's puzzle and congrats to Ryan Mathiason on his debut!!  I particularly liked the answer for "Kids in the '90s?"  I only got it when the puzzle was done and it took me a second.  Then came the realization and the smile.  Thank you!!
Great Monday puzzle. And, as always, a great intro by Sam!

This is a first for me as well--the first time I've had a friend get a puzzle published! What Ryan doesn't tell you is that in addition to his crossword skills, he was also a standout player on his high school basketball team. A genuine Renaissance man!

I always look forward to a Monday sprint after a Sunday marathon, but what should have been a quick puzzle turned into an average time killer!

I solved this one before bedtime on Sunday night. I wasn’t watching, but I’m guessing it would have been 15-20 minutes. But when I filled the last square it did not end and I knew I had a mistake somewhere.

I thought I must have been too tired to see it last night, but it took me another 25 minutes this morning.  Everything looked right. I finally found it because it was bothering me that I had never heard of the king of the Egyptian pantheon.

Ha! I had read the clue to be a noun meaning “mouth”, as in shut your YAP!  So I put down GOB-a perfectly fine fit, but how had I made it through 50 years of life and probably 25+ years of NYT puzzling without ever hearing of this god of gods, OMAN?  I finally deleted OMAN completely and thought to myself wouldn’t the king of the gods be the sun god RA? AMON RA? 🤦🏻‍♂️

It wasn’t the noun definition. It was the verb!


Not your fault Ryan! Great first puzzle and great Monday.

What's going on?

A new constructor!
Congratulations, Mr. Mathiason
FELIZ resolución, a todos!


Ryan, Ryan
Glad New York Times was buying
Ryan, Ryan, Ryan
After 30 NOS you kept on trying
You knew you had to find a way
To bring your crossword here today, yeah
Ryan, Ryan
Your words won't FADEAWAY
Just BALLUP those rejection letters
And TOIL on through Will's TSA*
You know you finally found a way
To bring some actuary ZEST today
TILDE lines over PESO signs
Don't punish me with glycyrrhizic STARANISE
HATS off from me
So you can see
Oh, ITSGROWINGON (ITSGROWINGONME)
ITSGROWINGON (GROWINGONME)
ITSGROWINGON (GROWINGONME)
ITSGROWINGON (GROWINGONME)
Right on, Ryan
Right on, 
Right on!

*Testing SHARP ASTUDENTS
Fun Monday puzzle. Not quite a personal best time, but close. And best of all it was Day 365 in my current (and longest) streak! Yay me!
Ha! 31D  [Kids in the 90s?]  had me confused until the very end!  😄

May have to listen to the Afro Cuban All-Stars tonight.

Son, opining to my brother that he wanted to live a life on the open road -- Oh you want to be a HOBO he responded.

Fun puzzle, although for a moment I thought I might be turning into a pillar of salt.  And, yes I know the difference between LEAH and Lot's wife.

Thank you Ryan and: Go Badgers

Yikes! Terrible time today.

It went very smoothly right up until the end, still got the "keep trying" message. I couldn't tell you how many times I went over every single answer before I realized I had a noun/verb confusion, leading me to fill in GoB for GAB.

Possibly my worst Monday time ever.

Other than that, fun puzzle. Thanks!

Just imagine - first, sixth, tenth, thirteenth, seventeenth, twentieth, … and then finally fortieth - YES! That’s the ticket. 

Ryan, your perseverance is highly remarkable. I love how it seems even the pros here seem to have had a struggle or two. 

Great outing and best of luck in your studies!

Please allow me, Ryan, to add my voice to gratulations for your magnificent achievement and resilience.

It should serve you well in life.

(This one goes out to @Sam Lyons)

"That Quickbeam, he is sure a stud Ent!"
 . . . or such was his reputation among the Entwives, once upon a time.

And since "Staran" can be either an erstwhile computer manufactured by the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation, or a Celtic musical quintet, I would not want to be turned into either.
Nice and easy today. Got it in less than 10 min.

A late puzzle find - quite remarkable. A Sunday from August 1, 1976 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title "Literary Curves." Some theme clue and answer examples: "Yorick's words?" THEVICTIMOFSKULLDIGGERY "Lady Macbeth's words?" HITTHEHIGHSCOTS "Hamlet's words?" THEGHOSTISCLEAR And some other theme answers: IMALLEARS YOUMUSTBECHOKING CHEEZITTHECOPSE ASPINGFORTROUBLE TALEOFWHOA ILOVEYOUSHREWLY Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=8/1/1976&g=82&d=A ....
great puzzleeee
We had a small poster which read "God made few perfect heads. The rest He gave hair."  My husband loved that one.
Hey, congratulations Ryan on your first NYT puzzle, and mega-props on your persistence! That's passion that deserves to be saluted.
Congratulations Ryan Mathiason on a fun Monday puzzle, your first NYT, and your perseverance. More please.

For anyone concerned about  hair loss, try:
My hormones have better things to do than grow hair."

Thanks Ryan! Wonderful puzzle, only one sports related clue, yay! my nemesis, but one I actually knew, though I'm not sure how! Loved 'kids in the 90s', clever, the pod for cooking, which I have used, a little Spanish, never took French, so often there's French! And the buzz cut took me back to when most kids had one, though we called it a crew cut. Anyway, congrats on achieving your goal, keep on going!

HATS off to Ryan on his debut.  A very evocative puzzle for a Monday, especially the mention of Grant Wood's "American Gothic".

The most famous Regionalist painters, Thomas Hart Benton, John Steuart Curry, and Grant Wood, were all associated with specific regions of the American Midwest. From Missouri, Kansas and Iowa, respectively.

Curry and Benton both have extensive murals in the Kansas and Missouri statehouses.  Both grappled over the realistic content of their works with unrealistic state legislatures.

Curry's famous "Tragic Prelude" was on the rock band Kansas'
debut album in 1974.  

Grant Wood's murals are in the Parks Library on the Iowa State University at Ames.

Curry was appointed as the first artist-in-residence at the College of Agriculture of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, which built him a small studio.  Many of his works are in your local museums.  The Emancipation Proclamation is in the Reading Room, Law Library, University of Wisconsin–Madison.

Many more of Curry's works are in the Whitney Museum of American Art in NYC.  

All three of these artists were controversial and at times New Yorkers, Parisians and attended The Kansas City Art Institute and the Institute of Art Chicago.

Thomas Hart Benton's most famous students were Dennis Hopper and Jackson Pollock.  I didn't know Pollock was also raised in Iowa.  

In Curry's Tornado over Kansas, I always imagine myself as the kid carrying the cat, heading for the root cellar because that's how it was.

Much fun!

My grandfather, who lived into his 90's, said barbers were always telling him he would go bald early. Then he'd grin and say, "You know what? Those barbers are all gone, and I still have my hair!" And so do I, at 71-- thanks, Grandpop!

PS @Sam Corbin, love your comments as always, but one nitpicky correction: WSW is west-southwest, not west BY southwest. There is a southwest by west, but that's a different point. Likewise, there is no north by northwest, Hitchcock notwithstanding :-)

My favorite clue from last week that has appeared in crosswords before:


Spanish uncle?  (2)(3)




NO MAS

@Lewis 

That had already been used?  I thought NOMAS for "Spanish uncle" was utterly brilliant.

Francis,

Last week's NOMAS clued as Spanish Uncle? was the third time in The Times. Lewis (et al) would know if it appeared earlier elsewhere.


Sat Jan 14, 2012
38A	
Spanish uncle? 	
Mark Diehl	
Shortz

Sat Nov 11, 2006	
26D	
Spanish uncle? 	
Brendan Emmett Quigley	
Shortz

@Francis 

It's the clue so nice, they had to use it thrice!

@Barry Ancona 

Amazing.  

I love this forum.  I really do.

It is absolutely heads and shoulders above any other cyber place I've ever found.

@Steve L 
I didn’t really know what to make of “;) and” ,which is what appeared on my iPad. I thought maybe it was the start of some emoticon improv.

@Steve L

Me too. I’m on the app on iOS

Mike,

Lettuce always enjoy your puns.

 (I relish them.)

@Mike 

There's a fine line between being hare-full and
                           ─────────────
                            being carrot-less

@Mike 

The farmer should know that one day does not warren feelings of hop-lessness.  It may seem like passing the buck, but he needs the doe.

@Mike
That tickles the bunny phone.

@Kelli 
I pictured a sprouting chia figure, too! “Chia pet” would have been a fun entry to sneak in somewhere.
@Strudel Dad a shaved head that would otherwise have hair could be described as bald. Just means no hair on it, not that hair is incapable of growing there. IMO
@Strudel Dad Most bald people aren’t completely bald. They often look completely bald because they shave off what little is left.

@Mark 
That's what my brother does.  (Vanity dictates, aside from his military career.)  All three of us kids--two girls, one boy--got The Genes.

@Mean Old Lady 
Yup, I got the genes, too. I am too lazy to shave daily. I just keep everything short and hope for the best. At my age, no one is looking. :)

@HeathieJ 

In these parts it's (so-called) ICE RAIN coming down.

@HeathieJ 

Oh, no!  I love snow.  I could enjoy snow 11 months of the year.  I've been known to say that I wish the melting point of water was 70 F, so that a lot of rain would be snow instead.

Snow is the only think that can make this black, ugly world beautiful.  So says the cynic.

My weather betê noire is tornadic thunderstorms.

@Francis 

No, you're right... I'd hate a tornadic thunderstorm more. 

And having a home and interest in the Caribbean, I worry a lot about hurricanes. 

So I guess snow can fall to my fourth hated!  ;-) 

Ah, it's okay... I have a roaring fire crackling away on the TV and I'm safe and warm inside. Also, I do hate it less now that I don't have to go to the office every weekday. 

Still, I dream of our lovely and colorful garden balcony!  ☺️

@HeathieJ 

The green is nice, I agree.  But it often comes with heat as well.

I spent 18 years in Tennessee, and left in great part because I was sick to death of heat and humidity.

My sympathies to those even farther south, and even hotter and more humid.

@HeathieJ 

I keep hearing from people in parts of the country who are getting SNOW and don’t want it. It would be more than welcome here, both for extending our ski season and giving us a hedge against a likely drought this summer.

@Eric Hougland 

I sure would love to send some your way!! 

I try not to complain about snow too much, it's a lot less than what I grew up with, but also I choose to live here and overall love it, but, or sneaking up on April and I'm ready for flowers and green grass! 

Also, I left you a comment about your review on the Sunday night puzzle... ☺️  

Shucks, I can't remember the original poster, but it's not too far from the top. If you're interested.

I get so confused sometimes because it is technically still Sunday night... But here we are on the Monday puzzle!

@Francis 

I haven’t followed the snow reports for northern Colorado, but it’s been a warm winter in the southern part of the state. We’d get a nice snowfall, say 10 or 12 inches, and it would be mostly gone by the next day.

@HeathieJ 

Thanks! I’ll try to find your comment.

@sotto voce 

I think society has actually come a long way on baldness.

We had Morey Amsterdam tormenting Richard Deacon's (and Carl Reiner's) cue tops.  

Now, it's quite the look.  And Patrick Stewart is a great example.

@Francis 

P. S.  The best of luck with your experience with cancer.  (Note:  I hate the metaphor of "battling" cancer, but I mean the same thing.)

@sotto voce My bald celebrity crush is Molly Tuttle. She has a great essay on her website about her alopecia. https://www.mollytuttlemusic.com/alopeciaareata And here she is doing her terrific song “Crooked Tree” with her band: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=aX3dPxXk-W4 As she sings: Oh, can't you see a crooked tree won't fit into the mill machine? They're left to grow wild and free Oh, I'd rather be a crooked tree ————————————— Personally, I can’t think of anything more gorgeous than a crooked tree.

@sotto voce 

Thank you for posting that gorgeous song. For some reason, when I think of Radiohead, I forget about The Bends, a totally underappreciated album... by me.  I think I'll listen to the whole thing again right now!

@sotto voce

A fair number of babies start out with a cue ball as well.

@Warren 

We were lucky to see her last summer at Grey Fox.  If you haven't seen her and get the chance, grab it.  The future of Bluegrass is in good hands.

@Nancy J. 

We’re seeing Jason Isbell in about a month. Molly Tuttle is the opening act. We’ll be sure to get there on time.

@Eric Hougland 

Lucky you!  I haven't seen him yet, but hope to.
@john ezra I LOVE THIS! Ha!

@john ezra 

Aw, you looked really cute with a tilde hairstyle.
I'm sorry it ran away with a question mark. 

But curly brackets are the cri du jour and very in demand. I've no doubt you're rockin' it!

@john ezra 

Ha! Excellent. This reminds me of Vonnegut’s sketches in his books.

Thanks all, unfortunately those pictograms in Vonnegut's Breakfast of Champions might be a little NSFW for this scene, but since I have a "So it Goes" baseball cap from the Vonnegut Museum in Indianapolis I can definitely relate!

@john ezra 

Brilliant, my friend. Just fantastic.

@john ezra 

Your knowledge of Vonnegut and you "So it Goes" baseball cap and that you've been to the Vonnegut Museum make me even more of a fan of yours than I was before.
@john ezra next time I have to try to describe my personal style I'm going with gothic hobo.

@Janis 

I'm in neighboring Minnesota, waiting and hoping.

@Francis 

Oh, I was reading in the Star Tribune about how all the manicurists have suddenly fled from Grand Marais and pretty much everywhere north of Duluth. 

Now I get it!! 😂

And seriously, I do get it!!

@Francis 
What would a MN'n be waiting and hoping for in a WI election?

@Hanson 

Like the whole nation wondering, is the money train stopped?

@Janis 

That's the million dollar question.

@Hanson 

What Janis said, and also, and this is only speaking for myself, some of us come from Wisconsin and have loads of friends and family and reasons to care there.
Francis, Here's a reminder for 47 Down: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N8NcQzMQN_U
@Francis It’s not easy to be stunningly brilliant AND devastatingly handsome 🙂

@Francis 

But at least you're still devastatingly handsome...

or so I've heard...

from you!!

🤣🤣

@M. Biggen 

Yeah, it absolutely isn't.  Sounds like you know what you're talking about.

@HeathieJ 

😂  I love that online I can be anything regardless of what I am IRL.

@Francis 

Indeed, my friend, it's the greatest beauty of the interwebs!!

@Barry Ancona 
I do hope it's Jose Feliciano....
Robin, King of the road. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WrhAC0dFis0

@Barry Ancona and now I'm picturing another king of the road, that being Andy Griffith walking down the dirt road with OPIE, aka Ron Howard, during the opening credits. They were both so darn good in that show, plus Ron is freaking adorable.

@Nora 
Little OPIE is 71 now and pretty close to BALD himself.  Not that there's anything wrong with that!

@Barry Ancona

I thought of that as soon as I filled in the answer. Thanks for the link!

@Andrzej 

It may take me some time to revamp my mental image of Andrzej given this new information.

@Francis 

I may not know what to do with all that hair but my hairdresser does, and it's nothing terribly extravagant. So don't get carried away too much.

Btw, i remember reading during the Covid pandemic about research on the influence of wearing masks on perceptions of attractiveness. Apparently, when we imagine what somebody may look like, we tend to go for the more attractive options. Thus, I am probably less dashing than you imagine me to be 😢

Also, it would be cool to research a person's reality, how it relates to their online persona, and then what a mental image of that person is in another's mind. Sounds like an idea for an episode of Rick & Morty 🤣

@acjones 

It’s hardly Ryan Mathiason’s first puzzle. He says in his constructor notes that it was his 40th submission to the NYT.

@dutchiris 

GOL (Groaning out loud)!!!!!!

@Mean Old Lady 

The story of my life! except that I still have enough left of the abundant locks from my life before the tyranny of the genes took over, in my mid 30s, that I just live with it.  My sisters and I were never bald, but from so thick to thin was scary.  Luckily, the texture of mine isn't as wispy as theirs was (thanks, Dad), so less covers more. A dermatologist once patted my shoulder and said, "Well, you'll never be bald as a man is bald." Oh swell.  

My oldest sister wore a wig, and it looked great.  A friend undergoing chemo has started wearing a wig, and it's a stunner—hers is gorgeous. I didn't lose much hair during chemo, and what I had before grew back—still thin, but there.  

I keep my hair short now, no wig so far, but it's comforting to know that the option is there.

@The X-Phile
“<3” is the emoticon that represents a heart. Sam chose to use brackets instead of parentheses, so the confusion is understandable.

@Mark 
Apparently the convention when writing about clues is that they should be bracketed, and the columnists follow that.

@Vaer - I didn’t know that was the convention,  so I have learned something. Yet, brackets are among the least used punctuation and I thought perhaps that is what threw The X-Phile off, as they had interpreted the bracket as part of the emoticon.

@Mark 

Part of the "fun" with emoticons is that it's hard to tell which punctuation marks are part of the emoticon and which are actual punctuation marks.

@The X-Phile 

In this case, I think the emoticon should have been in boldface to avoid confusion. Even though something is written correctly doesn't mean it will read well. I think many of us had to look twice at that to get it.

The plasticity of words is what I find most enchanting about crosswords.  And how long it can take for the meaning of a word to "flip" from one to another, like one of those optical illusions that have two equally meaningful ways to interpret the picture.
